title: How to Make Meghli

steps.headline: Add 1 cup of ground rice, 1 1/2 cups of white sugar, and 7 cups of water to a medium-sized cooking pot.
Season with 1 tablespoon of creole and 1 tablespoon of cinnamon.
Add 1 cup of boiled anise to the mixture.
steps.description: Just like preparing tea, boil water first and add the anise bag to it; then add it to the mixture.

steps.headline: Turn a small burner on the stove on high, with the pot on it.
steps.description: Stir the mixture at all times. This will help make sure the mixture doesn't stick to the bottom of the pot and burn. Wait for the mixture to boil.

steps.headline: Turn the stove down to low once the mixture starts to boil.
steps.description: Keep stirring it until the mixture starts to solidify. Don't let it become completely solid; just continue until it is not too liquid and not too solid.

steps.headline: Turn off the heat when it starts to solidify.
steps.description: Quickly pour it into small bowls, leaving some room for the toppings.

steps.headline: Let the bowls sit at room temperature until they cool.
steps.description: Then cover them with plastic wrap and place them in the refrigerator. Leave them there for at least an hour, to allow them to chill before you serve the dessert.

steps.headline: Add 1 cup (roughly a handful) of raw pistachios, raw almonds, raw cashews, and raw pine nuts, each to their own small bowl.
steps.description: Add some water to cover each. You should have 4 different toppings in 4 different bowls, in water.

steps.headline: Add the crushed coconut to the Meghli bowls.
steps.description: Spread the coconut out until the whole top is covered with a thin layer.

steps.headline: Add each of the toppings that you placed in the water.
steps.description: Sprinkle them over the Meghli and the crushed coconut, as desired.

text: Making the Meghli Add 1 cup of ground rice, 1 1/2 cups of white sugar, and 7 cups of water to a medium-sized cooking pot.  Season with 1 tablespoon of creole and 1 tablespoon of cinnamon.  Add 1 cup of boiled anise to the mixture. Just like preparing tea, boil water first and add the anise bag to it; then add it to the mixture. Mix the ingredients together.  Turn a small burner on the stove on high, with the pot on it. Stir the mixture at all times. This will help make sure the mixture doesn't stick to the bottom of the pot and burn. Wait for the mixture to boil. Turn the stove down to low once the mixture starts to boil. Keep stirring it until the mixture starts to solidify. Don't let it become completely solid; just continue until it is not too liquid and not too solid. Turn off the heat when it starts to solidify. Quickly pour it into small bowls, leaving some room for the toppings. Let the bowls sit at room temperature until they cool. Then cover them with plastic wrap and place them in the refrigerator. Leave them there for at least an hour, to allow them to chill before you serve the dessert. Adding Toppings to the Meghli Add 1 cup (roughly a handful) of raw pistachios, raw almonds, raw cashews, and raw pine nuts, each to their own small bowl. Add some water to cover each. You should have 4 different toppings in 4 different bowls, in water. Add the crushed coconut to the Meghli bowls. Spread the coconut out until the whole top is covered with a thin layer. Add each of the toppings that you placed in the water. Sprinkle them over the Meghli and the crushed coconut, as desired.
